metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This case challenges sexual abuse in shelter care facilities for unaccompanied minors.

target:
This case challenges sexual abuse in shelter care facilities for unaccompanied minors.

On July 14, 2024, the United States of America filed this lawsuit in the Western District of Texas against Southwest Key Programs, Inc., a nonprofit organization that provides housing and services to unaccompanied children who have entered the United States. Plaintiff alleged that from at least 2015 through at least 2023, multiple Southwest Key employees subjected unaccompanied children in their care to repeated sexual abuse, harassment, and misconduct and a hostile housing environment, including severe sexual abuse and rape, solicitation of sex acts, solicitation of nude photos, sexual comments and gestures, and inappropriate touching. Plaintiff alleged that these actions constituted a pattern or practice of discrimination in housing because of sex in violation of the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. § 3604(a); discriminated in the terms, conditions, or privileges of the rental or sale of dwellings, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of sex, in violation of 42 U.S.C. § 3604(b); made statements with respect to the sale or rental of dwellings that indicate a preference, a limitation, or discrimination based on sex, in violation 42 U.S.C. § 3604(c); and coerced, intimidated, threatened, or interfered with persons in the exercise or enjoyment of, or on account of their having exercised or enjoyed, their rights granted or protected by the Fair Housing Act, in violation of 42 U.S.C. § 3617. 74. 75. § 3602(b).

Plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief enjoining Defendant from continuing to engage in any discriminatory housing practice and engaging in sexual harassment; interfering with or threatening to take any action against any person engaged in the exercise or enjoyment of rights granted or protected by the Fair Housing Act; failing or refusing to take such affirmative steps to restore the victims; and failing or refusing to take affirmative steps to prevent the recurrence of any discriminatory conduct. Plaintiff also sought monetary damages to each person aggrieved by Southwest Key’s discriminatory conduct.

The case was assigned to Judge Alan D Albright.

On September 13, 2024, Defendant filed a motion to dismiss. Defendant argued that the Fair Housing Act does not apply to shelters; shelter care facilities are not “homes” under the definition of the Fair Housing Act; and the alleged conduct did not involve the initial provision of housing, or a “sale” or “rental.”

Before the court could rule on the motion to dismiss, on March 12, 2025, Plaintiff - now controlled by the Trump Administration - moved to dismiss the lawsuit with prejudice. This action followed the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) decision to stop placing unaccompanied children in Southwest Key shelters and to review the organization's federal grants. HHS stated that all children had been moved to other shelters due to ongoing concerns. According to Attorney General Pam Bondi, “Securing our border and protecting children from abuse are among the most critical missions of the Department of Justice and the Trump administration…under the border policies of the previous administration, bad actors were incentivized to exploit children and break our laws: this ends now” (HHS, DOJ Move to End Sexual Abuse and Harassment of Unaccompanied Alien Children in Shelters Operated by Southwest Key Programs [https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/hhs-doj-move-end-sexual-abuse-and-harassment-unaccompanied-alien-children-shelters-operated?utm_source=chatgpt.com]).

The case was closed on March 12, 2025.
target_paragraph: This case challenges sexual abuse in shelter care facilities for unaccompanied minors.

annotation.explanation: On July 14, 2024, the United States filed suit in the Western District of Texas against Southwest Key Programs, Inc., a nonprofit operating shelter care facilities that provide housing and services to unaccompanied minors who have entered the United States.

target_paragraph: On July 14, 2024, the United States of America filed this lawsuit in the Western District of Texas against Southwest Key Programs, Inc., a nonprofit organization that provides housing and services to unaccompanied children who have entered the United States. Plaintiff alleged that from at least 2015 through at least 2023, multiple Southwest Key employees subjected unaccompanied children in their care to repeated sexual abuse, harassment, and misconduct and a hostile housing environment, including severe sexual abuse and rape, solicitation of sex acts, solicitation of nude photos, sexual comments and gestures, and inappropriate touching. Plaintiff alleged that these actions constituted a pattern or practice of discrimination in housing because of sex in violation of the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. § 3604(a); discriminated in the terms, conditions, or privileges of the rental or sale of dwellings, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of sex, in violation of 42 U.S.C. § 3604(b); made statements with respect to the sale or rental of dwellings that indicate a preference, a limitation, or discrimination based on sex, in violation 42 U.S.C. § 3604(c); and coerced, intimidated, threatened, or interfered with persons in the exercise or enjoyment of, or on account of their having exercised or enjoyed, their rights granted or protected by the Fair Housing Act, in violation of 42 U.S.C. § 3617. 74. 75. § 3602(b).

annotation.explanation: Fair Housing Act — 42 U.S.C. § 3604(a) (sex discrimination in housing).
Fair Housing Act — 42 U.S.C. § 3604(b) (discrimination in terms, conditions, privileges, or services/facilities because of sex).
Fair Housing Act — 42 U.S.C. § 3604(c) (discriminatory statements indicating preference or limitation based on sex).
Fair Housing Act — 42 U.S.C. § 3617 (coercion, intimidation, threats, or interference with FHA rights).

annotation.checklist_item: Statutory or Constitutional Basis for the Case

annotation.explanation: Plaintiff: United States of America (filed the lawsuit in the Western District of Texas)
Defendant: Southwest Key Programs, Inc., a nonprofit organization that provides housing and services to unaccompanied children who have entered the United States

From at least 2015 to at least 2023, multiple Southwest Key employees allegedly subjected unaccompanied children in their care to repeated sexual abuse and harassment, including rape, solicitation of sex acts and nude photos, sexual comments/gestures, and inappropriate touching, creating a hostile housing environment.

The alleged abuse and harassment were asserted as a pattern or practice of sex-based discrimination in housing under the Fair Housing Act, including violations of 42 U.S.C. §§ 3604(a), 3604(b), 3604(c), and 3617.
Complaint filed by the United States on July 14, 2024, initiating the case in the Western District of Texas against Southwest Key Programs, Inc.

target:
This case challenges sexual abuse in shelter care facilities for unaccompanied minors.

Defendant argued that the Fair Housing Act does not apply to shelters; shelter care facilities are not “homes” under the definition of the Fair Housing Act; and the alleged conduct did not involve the initial provision of housing, or a “sale” or “rental.”

This action followed the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) decision to stop placing unaccompanied children in Southwest Key shelters and to review the organization's federal grants. According to Attorney General Pam Bondi, “Securing our border and protecting children from abuse are among the most critical missions of the Department of Justice and the Trump administration…under the border policies of the previous administration, bad actors were incentivized to exploit children and break our laws: this ends now” (HHS, DOJ Move to End Sexual Abuse and Harassment of Unaccompanied Alien Children in Shelters Operated by Southwest Key Programs [https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/hhs-doj-move-end-sexual-abuse-and-harassment-unaccompanied-alien-children-shelters-operated?utm_source=chatgpt.com]).

annotation.explanation: Declaratory relief.

Injunctive relief enjoining Defendant from: continuing discriminatory housing practices and sexual harassment; interfering with or threatening any person exercising Fair Housing Act rights; failing or refusing to take affirmative steps to restore victims; and failing or refusing to take affirmative steps to prevent recurrence of discriminatory conduct.
Monetary damages to each person aggrieved by Southwest Key’s discriminatory conduct.

The United States sought declaratory and injunctive relief to stop discriminatory housing practices and sexual harassment, protect Fair Housing Act rights, require restorative and preventive measures, and sought monetary damages for each aggrieved person.

annotation.explanation: Southwest Key moved to dismiss, arguing the FHA does not apply to shelters because shelter care facilities are not homes and the alleged conduct did not involve a sale or rental.

Defendant’s motion to dismiss filed on September 13, 2024; arguments: FHA does not apply to shelters; shelters are not “homes”; alleged conduct did not involve initial provision of housing or a sale/rental. No ruling issued before the case was later dismissed.
No ruling was issued on Defendant’s motion to dismiss (the court did not rule before the case ended).

annotation.checklist_item: Whether the Settlement is Court-enforced or Not

annotation.explanation: HHS stopped placing unaccompanied children in Southwest Key shelters, initiated a review of the organization’s federal grants, and moved all children to other shelters due to ongoing concerns.
Attorney General Pam Bondi publicly characterized the administration’s actions as prioritizing protection of children and border security, criticizing prior policies as enabling exploitation.
Before a ruling on the motion to dismiss, the United States moved to dismiss the case with prejudice on March 12, 2025, and the case closed the same day.
Plaintiff’s motion to dismiss with prejudice filed March 12, 2025; the case was closed the same day.
Case closed on March 12, 2025 following Plaintiff’s motion to dismiss with prejudice.
